CLUE: Powerful pre-1871 state of central Europe
OUTPUT: ['The Austro-Hungarian Empire was a multinational state that existed from 1867 to 1918, and it was one of the most powerful states in central Europe during that time period.', 'The empire consisted of two main parts: the Austrian half, which included the territories of Bohemia, Moravia, Silesia, and Carinthia; and the Hungarian half, which included the territories of Hungary proper, Transylvania, and the Banat.', 'The empire had a complex system of government, with the emperor serving as the head of state and the chancellor serving as the head of government.', 'The empire was also home to many prominent scientists and thinkers, such as Sigmund Freud and Ludwig Boltzmann.', 'The empire also had a complex system of social hierarchy and inequality, with significant disparities between the wealthy elite and the poorer masses.', 'Today, many of these regions are part of modern-day Austria, Hungary, and Slovakia.']
